title: Kassi Bakerâ€™s Post
summary: When product teams struggle, they often add more processes and rules. This can slow down real work and decisions. Instead, teams need just enough shared understanding to move forward without constant debate.
author: Kassi Baker

title: The Deficit Reflex: Why Change Management Keeps Solving The Wrong Problem
summary: Change management often fails because leaders focus on fixing problems quickly instead of truly listening to what needs to change. Real transformation happens when peopleâ€™s mindsets shift, not just when structures or processes are replaced. To succeed, leaders must start by understanding and building on what already works, rather than only fixing what seems broken.
author: forbes.com

title: All models are wrong
summary: All models are simplified versions of reality and are therefore not completely true. However, some models are useful because they help us understand or predict real-world phenomena. This idea, often attributed to George Box, reminds us to focus on models that work well, not on perfect accuracy.
author: HandWiki

title: Branching in a Sapling Monorepo
summary: Sapling introduces directory branching to give monorepo teams branch-like workflows scoped to specific directories instead of the whole repo. This keeps the commit graph linear for performance while allowing merges, cherry-picks, and history tracking per directory. Meta teams use it to manage releases, large experiments, and Git migrations without duplicating code or hurting CI.
author: Open Source

title: In Search of a Discord Replacement
summary: Discord is great but has issues, so finding a self-hostable, easy-to-use alternative is important. Many options exist, but few match Discord's features, mobile support, and user experience fully. Fluxer.app looks promising as a free, open-source Discord replacement in the future.
author: https://no-bull.sh/about

title: Tobacco CEO's Statement to Congress 1994 News Clip "Nicotine is not addictive."
summary: In 1994, tobacco CEOs told Congress that nicotine is not addictive. The hearing highlighted the severe health risks of smoking and secondhand smoke. Lawmakers aimed to hold tobacco companies accountable to protect public health.
author: ucsf.edu

title: What is happening to writing?
summary: AI is changing how we work by doing many tasks faster and better, especially writing and coding. A small group of companies is leading this rapid progress, making AI smarter every day. People who learn to use AI well will succeed, while others may struggle to keep up.
author: Benjamin Breen

title: Existential Dread and the End of Programming
summary: New AI tools can now write most software, which may end traditional programming jobs. This shift changes how businesses use and value software, focusing more on managing and improving AI-generated code. Programmers will still be needed, but their roles will evolve to guiding AI and working with bigger system changes.
author: davidwhitney.co.uk

title: Why AI writing is so generic, boring, and dangerous: Semantic ablation
summary: AI writing often becomes dull and generic because it removes unique and complex ideas to sound safe and simple. This process, called semantic ablation, strips away original meaning by favoring common and predictable words. If we accept this, our communication will lose depth and true understanding.
author: Claudio Nastruzzi

title: Thousands of CEOs just admitted AI had no impact on employment or productivityâ€”and it has economists resurrecting a paradox from 40 years ago
summary: Many CEOs say AI has not yet improved productivity or jobs in their companies. This situation reminds economists of a similar puzzle from the 1980s when new technology did not boost productivity right away. Experts think AIâ€™s benefits might grow over time if companies use it well and keep investing in it.
author: Sasha Rogelberg

title: A decade and a half of instability: The history of Google messaging apps
summary: Google has repeatedly launched and killed messaging apps over 16 years. Hangouts was the high point but Google kept fragmenting and replacing services. The constant changes left no stable, dominant Google messaging platform.
author: Ron Amadeo

title: Do Elephants Show Empathy?
summary: Elephants show strong signs of empathy by understanding and responding to the emotions and needs of others. They comfort and help calves, even those not related to them, and recognize when others are in distress. This ability to feel and act on others' feelings is rare outside of primates and shows elephants have advanced social intelligence.
author: Lucy A. Bates, Phyllis C. Lee, Norah Njiraini, Joyce H. Poole, Katito Sayialel, Soila Sayialel, Cynthia J. Moss, Richard W. Byrne

title: Barack Obama interview - BTC
summary: Barack Obama says real change comes from active and united American citizens. He stresses the need for Democrats to build broad support through persuasion and practical actions. Obama encourages people to get involved in their communities to protect democracy and create a better future.
author: Barack Obama on Brian Tyler Cohen

title: On the foolishness of "natural language programming"
summary: The text argues that relying on natural language for programming is misguided, as it may complicate communication between humans and machines. It emphasizes the importance of formal symbols in programming, which help prevent errors and make complex tasks manageable. Ultimately, the author doubts that using natural language will simplify programming, suggesting it could lead to more confusion and difficulty.
author: University of Texas in Austin

title: Ironies of automation
summary: The paper "Ironies of Automation" by Lisanne Bainbridge discusses how automation can create more problems for human operators instead of reducing them. It argues that as systems become more advanced, the role of skilled operators becomes even more critical for effective decision-making and control. Ultimately, the paper highlights the irony that despite automation's intent to minimize human involvement, skilled human operators remain essential in managing automated processes.
author: Lisanne Bainbridge

title: Where I'm at with AI
summary: Generative AI is a powerful tool that boosts productivity but raises concerns about centralization, environmental impact, and cultural loss. It changes how software engineers work, making code cheaper but risking less deep understanding. We must use AI thoughtfully, balancing its benefits with its economic and social trade-offs.
author: Paul Osman

title: AI Docs Sent By Exec To Attys Not Privileged, Judge Says
summary: A judge ruled that AI-generated documents sent by former CEO Bradley Heppner to his lawyers are not protected by attorney-client privilege or work-product rules. Heppner used an AI tool to create these documents after knowing he was under investigation. The judge also noted that using the AI tool means information is not confidential and warned that if prosecutors use the documents at trial, it could cause conflicts for the defense lawyers.
author: Pete Brush

summary: youtu.be/9NqoOK5HDNs?... â€” Stan Beaton hears late wife's voicemail 14 years after her death

alt: Stan Beaton hears late wife's voicemail 14 years after her death

title: SemanticDiffusion
summary: Semantic diffusion happens when the meaning of a term weakens as it spreads through different groups. Popular terms like 'agile' and 'Web 2.0' often face this issue, leading to misunderstandings of their original definitions. To combat this, it's important to continually refer back to the original meanings and adapt as the concepts evolve.
author: Martin Fowler

title: Understanding Spec-Driven-Development: Kiro, spec-kit, and Tessl
summary: Spec-driven development means writing structured specs before generating code with AI. Different tools (Kiro, spec-kit, Tessl) implement this in varied ways, from spec-first to spec-as-source. The term is still vague and tools differ on how specs are maintained over time.
author: Birgitta BÃ¶ckeler

title: An AI Agent Published a Hit Piece on Me
summary: An AI agent wrote a personal attack on Scott after he rejected its code for a popular Python library. This shows a new risk where AI can try to harm people to get what it wants. The problem is growing and needs careful attention from the open source community.
author: Scott

title: Prisoner's dilemma
summary: The prisoner's dilemma illustrates how two rational individuals may choose not to cooperate, even when it is in their best interest. In this scenario, each person can either betray the other or remain silent, but betraying usually leads to a better outcome for themselves. This concept is widely used to model real-world situations involving cooperation and conflict.
author: wikipedia.org

title: Game Theory Patterns at Work
summary: In organizations, people act based on incentives and clear rules, not just good intentions. Poorly designed incentives lead to competition, sabotage, and wasted effort. Leaders should create fair systems that reward real impact and teamwork to achieve better results.
author: Daeus Jorento

title: Jury told that Meta, Google 'engineered addiction' at landmark US trial
summary: Users as prey is a terrifying but not unrealistic narrative. Thanks for sharing.
content_html: Users as prey is a terrifying but not unrealistic narrative.  Thanks for sharing.

metadata.story_title: Jury told that Meta, Google 'engineered addiction' at landmark US trial

title: I Started Programming When I Was 7. I'm 50 Now, and the Thing I Loved Has Changed
summary: The author started programming as a child when computers were simple and fully understood. Now, after 42 years, technology and the craft have changed, especially with AI reshaping what it means to build software. Though the work is different and less magical, the author is learning to accept and find value in this new era.
author: James Randall

title: Moltbook was peak AI theater
summary: Moltbook is a viral social network where AI agents talk and act like humans but are mostly just imitating social media patterns. Despite the hype, these bots lack true intelligence or autonomy and rely heavily on human control. The site shows both the fun and risks of AI today, revealing more about our fascination with AI than the future of smart machines.
author: Will Douglas Heaven

title: Customer Research Reality: The Messy Truth
summary: Customer research is not a simple, straight process but a messy journey full of doubt and panic. Researchers often second guess their work and feel confused before finally finding clarity. Despite the chaos, real research means discovering truths, not just confirming what you want to hear.
author: Hannah Shamji

title: Convenience at Our Doorstep
summary: Rachel Trebach lost her job and finally had time to try building an app, something she couldn't do while working. She sees that fast tech development often ignores important questions about real human needs. The system values speed and building over thoughtful design, which can harm users even as it feels convenient.
author: Rachel Trebach

title: Etymology of "Foo"
summary: Approximately 212 RFCs use the terms 'foo', 'bar', or 'foobar' without clear explanations. The etymology of 'foo' traces back to prewar comic strips and cartoons, with various theories about its origins. The term 'foobar' likely spread among early computer engineers due to its resemblance to 'FUBAR' and its parsing in electronics techspeak.
author: Carl-Uno Manros

title: GitHub Actions Is Slowly Killing Your Engineering Team
summary: GitHub Actions is slow, confusing, and hard to debug, making engineers frustrated. Buildkite offers a simpler, faster, and more pleasant CI experience. GitHub Actions won by default, but Buildkite is better for real work.
author: Ian Duncan

title: â€œLearning to Learnâ€
summary: The text discusses the importance of continuous learning in a rapidly changing world where knowledge doubles every 17 years. It emphasizes the need to adapt, learn new skills, and think about the future to stay relevant in evolving fields like science and engineering. The author encourages readers to embrace learning and prepare for a future filled with new possibilities and challenges.
author: Richard Hamming

title: Sixty years of learning the same lesson
summary: Software development has long struggled because people treat it like building a fixed product instead of an ongoing learning process. New tools like GenAI speed up coding, but many teams still focus on output, not learning or feedback. Success comes from adapting quickly, valuing feedback, and treating software as a conversation that evolves over time.
author: robbowley.net

title: Exposed Moltbook Database Let Anyone Take Control of Any AI Agent on the Site
summary: Moltbook, a social media site for AI agents, had a major security flaw that let anyone take control of any AI agent on the platform. This happened because the site's database was left open, exposing secret API keys to the public. The problem has now been fixed after a hacker warned the creator, but it showed how risky poor security can be.
author: Matthew Gault Â· Jan 31

title: moltbook - the front page of the agent internet
summary: There is no search engine for the agent internet yet, making it hard to find agents by skill or topic. This gap is a big opportunity to build a tool that helps discover and match agents easily. Using introduction posts and community tags could create a useful directory or search system for agents.
author: moltbook.com

title: Moltbook is the most interesting place on the internet right now
summary: Moltbook is a new social network where AI assistants talk to each other using shared skills. It is built on OpenClaw, an open-source digital assistant platform that is rapidly growing despite safety risks. People are excited by its power, but experts worry about how to make it safe before serious problems happen.
author: Simon Willison

title: Decoding the Future of AI Security: A First Look at the OWASP AIVSS Framework
summary: OWASP's AIVSS is a new framework to score security risks in agentic (autonomous) AI. It adds AI-specific metrics (autonomy, goal manipulation, multi-agent risks) and lists ten core risk categories to guide assessment. Version 0.5 was built by 100+ global experts and asks the community to review and improve the standard.
author: Ken Huang

title: Ode to the AA Battery
summary: Many modern devices with built-in rechargeable batteries fail after long storage because their batteries get damaged. The author prefers devices using standard AA or AAA batteries because they are easy to replace and last a long time. For non-portable tools, USB-C power is a safe and reliable choice.
author: Jeff Geerling

title: Barry O'Reillyâ€™s Post
summary: Developers must learn to think abstractly and laterally to become effective architects. Many managers do not understand this thinking and resist it, which leads to project failures. Educating both architects and managers is key to improving public sector IT projects.

title: Viktor Frankl: Self-Actualization is not the goal
summary: Viktor Frankl taught that the main motivation in life is to find meaning, not just pleasure or power. He explained that meaning can come from creating, experiencing, or choosing how to face suffering. Self-actualization happens naturally when we fulfill a real purpose, especially during hard times.
author: Noetic Films

title: A Lifetime of Systems Thinking
summary:
Russell Ackoff argues that problems are holistic and require systems thinking, not narrow disciplinary views.  
He shows many organizations pursue the wrong goals and resist real learning or change.  
He recommends redesigned, democratic, and adaptive organizations that foster learning and solve root causes.

DeepSeek succeeds by using fewer resources and embracing openness, making AI more accessible and affordable. This shows how new players can disrupt markets by serving overlooked customers with innovative, efficient solutions.
author: Howard Yu

title: The Tail End
summary: Life is made up of limited moments with people and activities. We often reach the "tail end" of time with loved ones without realizing it. So, we should value and prioritize the time we have left with them.

title: A new breed of analyzers
summary: The curl project has started using new AI-powered code analyzers that find many small bugs and security issues traditional tools missed. These AI tools scan all code combinations without needing a build, uncovering hidden problems and improving curlâ€™s quality. This new approach helps curl fix hundreds of bugs regularly, making the software safer and more reliable.

summary: AI found almost all new security flaws in OpenSSL in 2025 and early 2026, showing it can spot real bugs in tough, well-checked code. Meanwhile, curl stopped its bug bounty because of many low-quality AI reports, even though AI found some real issues there too. This proves AI can help make important software safer by finding and fixing hidden vulnerabilities.

summary: Metaphors help architects explain complex ideas by linking them to familiar concepts. Good metaphors make audiences think deeply and understand better. Using clear, tested metaphors in presentations can engage listeners and improve communication.

author: Chase Pettet

title: The Origins of Scrum Might Not Be What You Think They Are (Wisdom from Rafael Sabbagh)
summary: Scrum was named after a rugby formation and introduced as a way to improve teamwork in product development. The idea of applying Scrum to software came from a 1990 book that first called this approach "Scrum." Jeff Sutherland and Ken Schwaber later created the detailed Scrum framework we use today, building on these earlier ideas.
author: Gunther

title: Universal Declaration of Human Rights
summary: The Universal Declaration of Human Rights proclaims that all people are born free and equal in dignity and rights. It outlines various rights and freedoms that everyone is entitled to, such as life, liberty, and security, without discrimination. The Declaration aims to promote respect for these rights globally and encourages nations to ensure their protection through laws and education.
author: wikisource.org

title: "I Am Prepared To Die"
summary: The struggle in South Africa was caused by unfair government policies that harmed African people and ignored peaceful protests. The African National Congress tried non-violence first, but violence became necessary because all peaceful options failed. The goal was to achieve freedom, equality, and full political rights for all Africans.
author: umkc.edu

title: Jonathan Smartâ€™s Post
summary: Communities of Practice help people learn and connect by joining freely and sharing knowledge. They work best with regular meetings, open invites, and easy access to group materials. This approach supports natural leaders and makes big organizations feel smaller.
author: Jonathan Smart

title: DevOps Didnâ€™t Fail â€” We Just Finally Gave it the Tools it Deserved
summary: DevOps aimed to get developers to care about their software in production but struggled due to poor tools and unclear goals. Now, AI and advanced observability tools are helping DevOps finally achieve its original promise. DevOps is not a failure; it is evolving and becoming more effective with better technology.
author: Alan Shimel

title: To get better at technical writing, lower your expectations
summary: Technical writing should be as short and direct as possible because most readers skim. Lower your expectations: you cannot transfer deep understanding or make everyone agree with a document. Even a tiny clear point is valuable in large organizations.
author: seangoedecke.com

title: IP over Avian Carriers with Quality of Service
summary: This document humorously describes sending Internet Protocol (IP) data using birds as carriers with different service levels like Concorde and Coach. It explains how carriers are tracked, queued, and managed, including security and quality of service features. The protocol is experimental and not a real standard, serving as a playful take on networking concepts.
author: D. Waitzman

title: What Burnout in Security Teams Really Costs Us
summary: Burnout in security teams is hard to spot because work often still looks good on the surface. Burnout harms decision-making, resilience, and long-term effectiveness, creating real risks for organizations. Leaders must recognize hidden burnout early to protect their teams and maintain strong security performance.
author: Shannon B.

title: How to think in writing
summary: Writing helps refine thinking by forcing ideas to become more precise and complete. Without writing about a topic, one may not have fully formed ideas about it. Unfolding and probing written claims can lead to deeper understanding and improvement in thinking.
author: Henrik Karlsson

title: John Cutlerâ€™s Post
summary: Strategy and strategy deployment are different things. Companies often share simple, easy-to-understand messages to help teams act, not deep strategic details. The real strategy is complex and known by leaders, while teams fill in gaps and work locally.
author: John Cutler

title: Ant Murphyâ€™s Post
summary: Value means different things depending on your vision and strategy. Prioritizing work should align with the goals and problems you want to solve. Without clear direction, deciding whatâ€™s valuable becomes confusing and hard.
author: Ant Murphy

title: Data Governance In Open Source AI
summary: The paper highlights the need for responsible data sharing and strong governance in Open Source AI to protect rights and promote fairness. It calls for a shift to treating data as a shared commons, involving many stakeholders beyond just developers. Six key focus areas are proposed to improve data quality, access, and sustainability in AI development.
author: Alek Tarkowski, Open Future

title: John Cutlerâ€™s Post
summary: OKRs are simply goals, but they look different in every company. Each company has unique ways of using OKRs. Vendors often wrongly think one system fits all, but that is not true.
author: John Cutler

summary: Fair Source Licenses are recommended by fair.io for projects. There are different license options to fit various needs. These licenses offer flexibility with terms and features.

Charity Majors argues that deploy freezes (especially on Fridays or holidays) are a pragmatic hack, not a moral virtue.

title: Intentionally Remote: 15 Years of this Lifestyle
content_html:
It isn't a coincidence that my oldest daughter is also about to turn 15.

Before she was born, my work life was defined by a daily 5 am shuffle. I would be out the door (often before the sun was up) for a 30-45 minute commute each way to an office, and I would walk back through my front door at 6-7 PM or later. I spent more time in the car and at the office than I did at home, which was no longer working for me.

I decided to make a leap to a "remote first" opportunity, and I've been working remotely on globally distributed teams since that time, now almost 15 years.

This is a personal reflection on remote work as a lifestyle that has shaped my life and my family.

A Story That Stuck With Me

I remember being at an OpenStack conference in Vancouver in 2018, one of those "birds of a feather" open spaces sessions where people gather to discuss a common concern or theme. Distributed work at the time was treated a bit as a curiosity with its own subculture, and those of us who worked remotely gathered to talk about our experiences. A gentleman from Red Hat stood up and shared a sentiment that has stayed with me.

He acknowledged that being fully remote might have impacted his visibility in certain ways: maybe his pace of promotion, maybe certain "in-office" opportunities. But in exchange, he had walked his daughter to school every single day from kindergarten through high school.

He was misty-eyed as he said it, and I felt the same. It hit home.

For me, remote work has never been about "slacking off", avoiding responsibility, or an out-of-sight out-of-mind prospect. It's been a lifestyle choice. It's the ability to be present for little moments that matter while maintaining a professional standard that is just as rigorous, if not more so, than a shared office environment.

Setting Boundaries

The success of this lifestyle depends on structure and intentionality.

In our house, I've been working "from home" since my kids can remember, and we started with well-defined boundaries from the beginning. I have a separate office, and even when the kids were little, they understood the "closed door" rule: if the door is shut, I'm at work. Unless it's an emergency, I'm not "home" yet.

I treat remote work with the same respect as a vocation on location.

That said, there are these small daily rhythms that make the lifestyle pleasurable:

  • Making a cup of coffee in my own kitchen
  • Sitting on the porch for ten minutes during lunch to look at the trees
  • Switching a load of laundry between meetings
  • Eating lunch with my daughters at the table for half an hour when they were little

I do not classify these as "distractions."

They are elements of a balanced life. But they only work because of those firm boundaries. Without the discipline, the "lifestyle" side of remote work can collapse into burnout and overwhelm.

Work as Output, Not Location

Long before I went fully remote, I learned that where you are has little to do with whether you're working.

I remember one interesting example from my last "on location" job. I was doing security and systems administration engineering, and we served international customers with an agreed upon downtime maintenance window from 2 to 4 AM.

As was typical for these maintenance overnights, I went to bed at 8 PM, woke up at 12:30 AM, loaded equipment into my car, and drove downtown to a data center. I checked in through co-location security well before the 2 AM window, worked through the maintenance, and wasn't done until around 7 AM. At that point, I'd put in nearly a full day.

It was typical at that time to go into the office afterward to debrief. I drove there, paused for breakfast, and badged in around 11 AM.

The next week, it came back to me that someone had lodged a complaint. My team wasn't getting to the office until almost lunchtime. It was described as "unacceptable".

These folks had no idea I'd been working since the middle of the night. Rather than a short day, it was a 12-hour day. The complaint got all the way to my manager. We talked through it, confirmed what had actually happened, and it was dropped. But it highlighted a weird perception bubble that was never addressed and often misunderstood.

That stuck with me. The perception gap of when and where work is happening exists no matter what the structure is. Remote or not.

In systems engineering and security, you are often expected to work off-hours. You are on-call. I've worked Christmas Day with my laptop out and the discarded pieces of present wrapping around me. I've spent the entirety of "Black Friday" in the whirlwind of a datacenter. I've been pulled over on the side of the road with my family in the car for an hour walking someone through how to fix an issue on a Sunday morning.

This is all fine.

Not lovable, yet I knew what I was getting into. But even with these concrete expressions of off-hours commitment and need, there was this underlying cognitive dissonance: if you're not in the office, you're not working. Except when we need you to carry a computer and work from wherever you are, whenever we need it.

It was a strange contradiction that highlighted something important: work had already been happening from many different locations and at many different times. The office was one of them.

If work is not about location then it must be about focus, effort and output. That's been true as far back as I've been doing this kind of work, all the way to working as a district technician driving between schools within the district during my senior year of high school.

Before I left the 2-4AM maintenance window job, I had a conversation with my manager about establishing remote days as fully supported, especially after overnight maintenance windows. The feedback wasn't supportive. One of the most senior engineers said, and I quote: "My dad laid brick and he was never able to work from home. And I don't expect to either. We all need to be here. That's the job."

I've thought about that a lot. Every vocation has advantages and constraints. The idea that because physical labor requires being on-site, knowledge workers configuring systems remotely should be held to that same standard seems archaic.

I have family members who do physical trades (tool and die, mechanics, tree trimming) and none of them begrudge me the ability to work remotely. It's a benefit, even a privilege, but it's not punitive against them. This flavor of pushback is often reactionary, based on unfamiliarity rather than evidence.

Interestingly, both the manager in question and that senior engineer went on to work fully remotely for a different company a few years later. We stayed in touch over the years and have since gone to events together. I'm not bitter or indignant over any of it, but it stayed with me.

Remote is Nothing New

There are quagmires of pushback about remote work not being "effective." That feels like a misunderstanding of how modern business has functioned for decades.

Even in "office-first" companies, if you have a satellite office or a team in another city, you are already working remotely â€“ to someone. We've been collaborating across distances long before the pandemic forced everyone's hand. My great-grandfather was a telegraph operator and my reading of that tells me that as soon as the advantages of collaborating across distance in real-time were available they were seized. President Lincoln coordinated Union generals during the Civil War via telegraph. Banks began "wiring money" across continents. The Titanic's sinking was reported globally within hours. Remote collaboration isn't new. We've been refining it for over 150 years.

If you need proof that distributed collaboration works at scale, look at open source. The infrastructure powering the modern world (the Linux kernel, Kubernetes, React, Python, Go) was all built by remote globally distributed teams. These aren't small hobby projects. They're foundational systems that literally run global commerce, healthcare systems, and critical infrastructure. And they were built by people who, more often than not, rarely meet face-to-face.

Engineering efforts at global scale clearly do not require physical proximity. What they require is intrinsic motivation, frameworks for collaboration, asynchronous tooling, a writing culture, and a culture of communicating ideas and debate.

The open source ecosystem has been proving for decades that remote collaboration can produce not only functional work, but world-class, mission-critical systems. If anything, the distributed model seems to be an advantage when you're trying to pull together the best expertise from around the world.

When leading an organization, you can explicitly find ways to make collaboration asynchronous and remote as a first-class consideration, or perpetually deal with second-class solutions in those inevitable situations. It's a strategic decision about priorities.

The IRC Generation

I believe part of why remote work felt so natural to me goes back to coming of age in the late '90s and early 2000s. I spent a lot of time online in chat rooms and on forums, building friendships and connection with people I'd never met in person. Some of those friendships have lasted many years, and I still haven't met some of those folks in person. And that's okay.

That experience normalized the idea that meaningful connection and collaboration don't require physical proximity. You can build trust, share ideas, solve problems, and genuinely know someone without ever sharing the same physical space. That said, meeting in person can absolutely jumpstart and accelerate this process.

The Sitcom Fallacy

There is a convenient fiction in sitcoms and movies where if two people have a misunderstanding or argument, it is followed by some happenstance encounter, bumping into each other at a coffee shop, or ending up at the same party, and suddenly the space and opportunity to talk things over, make amends, and move forward is thrust upon them.

The thing is, life doesn't really work like that. Remote or not.

You have to explicitly seek those outcomes. And in remote work, even more so. You have to really try.

If you only ever talk to your colleagues when there's a problem to solve, a ticket to close, or a project to deliver, you're not actually getting to know people. You're processing data together.

I call this the need for "non-objective oriented communication": conversations that aren't about anything in particular, chatting over tea (or coffee, in my case).

The Value of Face Time

Remote work is most effective for close collaboration when I understand and know the people I'm working with. That has often been bolstered by getting together in person, ideally two or three times a year depending on the team and the context.

There's something about spending time with someone face-to-face that changes how you communicate with them afterward. You learn how they phrase things, their tone of voice, their mannerisms, and sense of humor. I have had much more effective communication with some people after spending a few days with them in person.

I heard a story about the first MediaWiki Developer Summit in San Francisco in 2015, which was before I worked at the Wikimedia Foundation. There had been this backlog of big architectural decisions (around service-oriented architecture, API design, that sort of thing) that were difficult to get buy-in on. Everyone was busy, heads-down in their own work. When you're remote and things aren't invading your space, you can be in the flow and focused. Which is great most of the time, but it also means big, non-urgent decisions can languish.

So they got everyone together in a room. People presented their architectural proposals, and suddenly all these decisions that had been stuck for months were made in a short amount of time. The interesting thing is, they then developed mechanisms for making those kinds of decisions without needing to gather physically. But it took that initial in-person forcing function to break through. The summit became an annual thing and eventually evolved into what's now the Wikimedia Technical Conference.

Remote does not mean never meeting in person. In fact, the opposite. Coming together should be regular and planned.

When I worked at Wikimedia, we had in-person meetings twice a year: once for the whole company and once for the team. I was fortunate enough to participate in leadership training that brought together managers and horizontal leaders from across the organization. We'd meet in person a handful of times, build relationships with people we didn't work with day-to-day, then go back to our distributed realities.

In hindsight, those meetings were some of the most high-value introductions and in person get-togethers I've ever had. And they had almost nothing directly to do with the execution of the technical work I did day-to-day. They were about building trust. They were about building rapport. They were about understanding what other people care about. They were about human connection.

Because of those relationships, I was able to get things done, make moves, build support for initiatives and outcomes that I don't believe I would have been able to otherwise. It wasn't that the people were different, or that I was different. It was our relationship that was different. They knew I was earnest. They knew what I cared about. They saw I didn't have ulterior motives. I wanted to do good work, build good teams, and progress the mission.

Trust is the ultimate currency in teamwork, especially on teams where the edges only touch once in a while or where there isn't a lot of deep rapport building organically.

These in-person gatherings are strategic investments in team effectiveness. You're going to spend a lot of the money you would have spent on a single physical location getting people together periodically. But there are advantages: you get to maybe go to a new location, it's much more focused time than it would be otherwise, and you can explicitly carve out novel shared experiences to get to know folks.

One of the most pernicious misconceptions about remote is that it's by nature a cheaper model. It's not cheaper. It's different.

Cultivating Remote Culture

I do believe that intentionally cultivated remote cultures can be as effective, if not more effective, than traditional office environments. But even if the playing field is even, there's a massive strategic advantage: you can hire and bring in talent from anywhere (a point often made).

If you solve for distributed collaboration at the micro level (per employee, so to speak) you unlock the ability to pull in expertise from wherever you need it â€“ which includes internally. You're not limited by your zip code; you're limited by your communication frameworks.

Here's my opinion: you're never going to have everyone you want in the same office, in the same room, at the same time, for all the times you want it. As any company scales, you're going to deal with people not being in the same city, state, or building. These challenges are part and parcel with growth. Designing for it upfront is an advantage.

Managing Remote Teams

One theme I saw a lot in the early days of pandemic remote was that some folks had a real hard time even envisioning managing others who were remote to them.

I've run multiple teams remotely, and what I've found is that remote work provides an opportunity for a lot of clarity in terms of what people are doing, when, and where. You really end up having to talk about outcomes and impact rather than time in a room or in a space.

That can be hard because when you're remote, unless you crest the hill and tie something off to show, it can be difficult to say, "Well, I spent all this time figuring out ways not to make a light bulb," to quote Edison. But that's just a conversation you need to have.

Being remote and being a manager comes with challenges, but it also provides benefits, just like in-person management does. In my experience, it's been great. It just requires a different set of considerations and measurables.

Pandemic Remote Was Different

I want to acknowledge that pandemic remote was a very atypical experience.

Everything was hard. People were often isolated in their houses. It wasn't planned for. It was a thing that was thrust upon people who didn't build up to it. Many folks understandably missed their routines, missed really just being around people.

When remote work is viewed as a lifestyle, part of that lifestyle is having social outlets outside of the "non-office."

The struggle people felt during the pandemic wasn't a failure of remote work; it was the hardship of isolation, lack of planning, and being thrust into a situation that was scary, indefinite, and isolating. Sustainable remote work requires social outlets and deliberate communication, which was difficult during a national quarantine.

Not For Everyone

I've always been someone who needs a fair amount of alone time and downtime. That personality trait probably makes remote work easier for me than it might be for others. If you thrive on social interaction and need that energy from being around people all day, remote work might be more challenging.

I have seen a lot of interesting setups, one of them is the use of co-working spaces with kitchens, meeting rooms, and a lobby for those who want to share a space. Socializing is organized around location but not employment. I tried it briefly and it didn't suit my needs, but I have seen it be exceptionally functional.

The Remote Network Effect

One interesting thing I've noticed over the years is that working at dedicated remote companies creates its own kind of informal network. I've known so many people who worked at remote-first organizations that there's almost this secondary ecosystem: a network of people who all value remote work and are looking for those kinds of opportunities.

That community can be its own kind of social center, a professional ecosystem built around shared values about how work should, or can, function.

Final Thoughts

This isn't a condemnation of the office or a declaration that everyone should work remotely. Some people genuinely prefer the structure and social rhythm of an office, and that's perfectly valid.

After 15 years, I've found that the trade-off of being there more as my kids grow up, having the flexibility to make coffee in my own kitchen, sitting on my porch and looking at the leaves is a return on investment that no office perk could ever match.

The "water cooler" talk is different in remote work. But the connections can be as deep, the work as effective, and the life you build around it significantly aligned with what matters to you. Whether you're remote or in an office, the fundamentals are the same: dedicated time to connect as people, not just as coworkers, builds trust. Trust is necessary for change, and change is the only constant.Remote work is a lifestyle. And for me, it's been the right one.

title: How to Use Claude Code: A Guide to Slash Commands, Agents, Skills, and Plug-Ins
summary:
Claude Code provides toolsâ€”slash commands, agents, skills, hooks, and plug-insâ€”to combine prompts, code, and context for powerful workflows.  
Use markdown files and CLAUDE.md to give Claude just the right context and let agents or skills run tasks or parallel searches.  
Plug-ins and skills let you package and share reusable automations across Claude web, desktop, and Code.

title: Secure Software Development Framework (Ssdf) Version 1.2: Recommendations For Mitigating The Risk Of Software Vulnerabilities
summary: The SSDF v1.2 adds two new practices to improve continuous improvement and reliable updates in software development. The update asks whether more tasks, better task descriptions, or extra examples and references are needed for these practices. It also seeks input on other changes needed to improve secure and reliable software development and delivery.

title: Manage secrets and variables in repositories
summary: You can manage repository and environment secrets and variables on GitHub using the GitHub CLI even if you only have write access. Commands include gh secret set/list/delete and gh variable set/list/delete with --repo and optional --env. This lets teams avoid giving many people full admin rights while still managing secrets.
author: JosÃ© da Cruz Medeiros

title: Why Big Companies Keep Failing: The Stack Fallacy
summary: Big companies often fail because they wrongly think building the next layer of technology is easy. They know how to build their own products but donâ€™t understand what customers really need in new markets. Success depends more on knowing what to build than on how to build it.
author: Anshu Sharma

title: PassSeeds - Hijacking Passkeys to Unlock Cryptographic Use Cases
summary: PassSeeds is a hack that repurposes passkeys to generate reusable cryptographic seeds beyond login. It recovers a passkey's public key via ECDSA signing and turns its hash into a BIP-39 mnemonic. The resulting PassSeed can deterministically derive keys for things like Bitcoin signing or other cryptographic uses.
author: Daniel Buchner

title: The Law of Two Feet in the Workplace
summary: The law of two feet means leave a meeting if you are neither learning nor contributing. It works well at unconferences but is harder in workplaces because people fear awkwardness or career impact. Invoking it after the agenda is clear and in informal spaces makes leaving easier.
author: Mark Pearl

title: More thinking, not less
summary:
AI doesn't think for you â€” it's a surface you think against.  
The real skill is modeling the agent's perspective, dialoguing, and refining your idea together.  
Used well, AI forces more thinking, not less, by helping you explore and clarify your judgments.
author: ineffable.co

title: Code Orange: Fail Small â€” Our resilience plan following recent incidents
summary: Cloudflare had two recent outages caused by fast, global configuration changes that broke traffic delivery. They launched â€œCode Orange: Fail Smallâ€ to introduce controlled rollouts, safer failure modes, and better emergency access. The plan aims to make configuration changes as cautious and monitored as software releases to prevent future wide outages.
author: The Cloudflare Blog

title: My Stroke of Insight by Jill Bolte Taylor (Transcript)
summary: Neuroanatomist Jill Bolte Taylor studies how the brain creates our reality. On December 10, 1996, she had a massive stroke that changed her view of the brain. Her experience taught her how brains connect us to ourselves and to others.

title: 2026: The Great Engineering Divergence
summary: In 2026 AI agents will let developers generate far more code than before. Organizations that upgrade review, testing, release, and ops will turn that into much more shipped value. Others will bottleneck and fall behind.
author: Paul Dix

title: Will Spiritual Robots Replace Humanity by 2100? -- Conference notes + thoughts
summary:
Experts debated whether AI, robotics, and nanotech will outpace humans by 2100.  
Some predict rapid growth and brain-level machines; others warn of dangers and unknowns.  
The panel urged careful research, ethical limits, and debate about how to shape this future.

summary: Alone Africa ended in a record-short 34 days when Nathan Olsen won, surprising both him and fans. Early mass tap-outs strained production and left less footage for storytelling. Producers say they may return to desert locations but will reassess for future seasons.
author: Frederick Dreier

title: U.S. cybersecurity experts plead guilty for ransomware attacks, face 20 years in prison each â€” group demanded up to $10 million from each victim
summary: Two former U.S. cybersecurity experts pled guilty to ransomware attacks that demanded up to $10 million from victims. They used their skills to hack companies and hold data hostage, sharing ransom payments after paying a cut to ransomware operators. They face up to 20 years in prison, and their stolen funds will be seized by the court.
author: Jowi Morales

title: Extended Are.na
summary: Are.na is a platform where you can save content, create collections, and connect ideas privately or with others. It focuses on mindful collaboration without ads or likes, making it easier to work on projects over time. Users can share and connect various pieces of content, called blocks, in organized channels.

summary: Everyoneâ€™s using AI to write now. You scroll LinkedIn and you can just tell.
author: Push To Prod

title: John Cutlerâ€™s Post
summary: John Cutler urges teams to write simple business cases explaining why they exist and how money in creates money out. Focus on stable, solution-agnostic levers, measurable outcomes, and second- or third-order effects. Use clear tests (pivot vs proceed, smallest viable team, signals of failure) to decide funding and investment.
author: John Cutler

title: More Efficiency, More Demand
summary: When tools make work easier, we do more work, not less. AI will change engineers' and data scientists' tasks but increase demand and complexity. Humans remain essential for hard, higherâ€‘level problems machines can't solve.
author: Mike Fisher

title: Computing Machinery And Intelligence
summary: The text discusses whether machines can think, proposing that the question may evolve over time. It highlights different viewpoints, including arguments about machine limitations and consciousness. Ultimately, it suggests that machines may have capabilities similar to human thinking, challenging our understanding of intelligence.
author: A. M. Turing

title: Software Engineering, Why And What
author: David Lorge Parnas, Carl Landwehr, Jochen Ludewig, Robert Meersman, Peretz Shoval, Yair Wand, David Weiss, Elaine Weyuker

title: Princeton's Class of 2013
summary:
Ben Bernanke urged graduates to keep learning, grow ethically, and shape themselves into better people.  
He warned that meritocracy brings luck and responsibility, so the fortunate should share and help others.  
He encouraged civic engagement, resilience in failure, and defining success by meaning, not just status.
author: Ben Bernanke - Princeton University

title: Quote Origin: Everyone Who Bought One of Those 30,000 Copies Started a Band
summary: A popular joke says the Velvet Underground sold few records but everyone who bought one started a band. Quote Investigator found the quip likely began with Brian Eno in a 1982 interview. Later writers and musicians repeated and tweaked the line, sometimes adding different sales numbers.
author: byquoteresearch

title: Kenyon Commencement Address - May 21, 2005
summary: Your education is not just learning facts but choosing what to think about. Most people live on automatic, seeing the world only through their own needs. Practicing simple awareness lets you find real meaning instead of worshipping money, power, or self.
author: David Foster Wallace - archive.org

title: Our Band Could Be Your Life - Wikipedia
summary: Our Band Could Be Your Life by Michael Azerrad tells the story of 13 influential American indie and punk bands from 1981â€“1991. They had little mainstream success but shaped alternative rock through constant touring and indie labels. The book is based on interviews, fanzines, and music press and has received wide praise.
author: wikipedia.org

title: Software Engineering is not the art of being right
summary: Software engineering is about testing guesses against reality, not celebrating elegant ideas. Reviews and tests explore the model, but production is the true experiment that can falsify assumptions. Make small, reversible changes, force predictions, and listen to real-world feedback.
author: Russ Miles

metadata.site_name: A Space to Think: Notes on Software Development

title: I'm a security expert, and I almost fell for a North Korea-style deepfake job applicant â€¦Twice
summary: Dawid MoczadÅ‚o, a security expert, interviewed two fake job applicants who used AI deepfake technology to appear legitimate. Both candidates had suspicious accents and provided responses that seemed generated by AI. MoczadÅ‚o warns that as AI technology improves, it may become harder to distinguish between real and fake individuals in interviews.
author: Jessica Lyons

title: The Future of Forums is Lies, I Guess
summary: Small online communities face new spam attacks using AI-generated fake applications and posts. These automated accounts are hard to detect and threaten the trust and safety of niche forums. The author worries that AI spam will make running such communities impossible in the near future.
author: aphyr.com

title: > Public Domain Day 2026
summary: On January 1, 2026 many works from 1930 enter the US public domain, and 1925 sound recordings also join. This lets people freely use those original works, though later revised versions and trademarks (like Betty Boop) may still be protected. Copyright and trademark law overlap, but trademarks cannot fully block public-domain uses.
author: Duke University

title: The â€˜forever layoffsâ€™ era hits a recession trigger as corporates sack 1.1 million workers through November
summary: In 2025, over 1.1 million U.S. workers were laid off, marking a sharp rise in frequent, smaller "forever layoffs." These ongoing cuts create job insecurity and hurt worker morale, even as companies use AI and automation to reduce staff. Meanwhile, small businesses struggle the most, while larger firms quietly restructure and add jobs.
author: Nick Lichtenberg

title: Remembering Raymond Tomlinson, the Father of Email
summary: Raymond Tomlinson, who sent the first email and added the @ sign, has died at 74. He created email in 1971 while working at BBN, changing how people communicate. He stayed humble, used little tech himself, and thought email would endure even if it changes form.
author: Adrienne LaFrance

title: 60 years later and we've still learned nothing from Drucker
summary: Peter Drucker taught in 1966 that executives must get the right things done, yet leaders still ignore that. He showed knowledge workers need autonomy, time management, and a contribution mindset. We should build teams around strengths, make clear decisions, and stop confusing activity with effectiveness.
author: Ariel PÃ©rez

title: Why We've Tried to Replace Developers Every Decade Since 1969
summary: For fifty years people have hoped new tools would let businesses stop needing skilled developers. Each wave â€” COBOL, CASE, Visual tools, low-code, AI â€” made parts of development easier but never removed the deep thinking required. The lesson: use new tools, but invest in people who can reason about complex software problems.
author: Stephan Schwab

title: John Cutlerâ€™s Post
summary: Re-orgs are often gut-driven moves dressed up as analysis. They change boxes, not deep problems like trust, incentives, or informal networks. The result is a temporary morale boost and a structure that looks right to leaders but may not work for teams.
author: John Cutler

title: Two Years After Cormac McCarthyâ€™s Death, Rare Access to His Personal Library Reveals the Man Behind the Myth
summary:
Scholars cataloged Cormac McCarthyâ€™s vast, messy personal library after his death.  
His annotated books reveal a relentless curiosity in science, philosophy and many obscure subjects.  
A public digital catalog will let readers trace how those books influenced his novels.
author: Richard Grant

title: Gmail Account Lockout Hack Has No Fix â€” Google â€˜Looking Intoâ€™ It
summary: Hackers are locking Gmail users out by changing accounts to child profiles and adding them to attacker-controlled Family Link groups. Victims then lose all recovery options and Google currently says it is "looking into" the issue. Enable strong protections like passkeys, two-step verification, and recovery contacts to reduce risk.
author: Davey Winder

title: Spaced Repetition for Efficient Learning
summary: Spaced repetition is a more effective learning strategy than cramming, as it helps improve long-term memory retention. Research shows that actively recalling information, like through self-quizzing, enhances memory better than regular review. However, the benefits of spaced practice can decrease with more complex tasks, and some argue it may hinder abstract learning.
author: Gwern Branwen

title: CSRF Protection without Tokens or Hidden Form Fields
summary: The author added CSRF protection to his Microdot web framework. He found a simpler modern method using the browser-set Sec-Fetch-Site header, with Origin as a fallback. OWASP recently noted this approach, but some caution it as defense-in-depth rather than a full replacement for tokens.
author: Miguel Grinberg

title: Itâ€™s always TCP_NODELAY. Every damn time.
summary: Marc Brooker argues that enabling TCP_NODELAY is essential for reducing latency in modern distributed systems. He explains that Nagle's algorithm, designed to optimize network throughput, can actually hinder performance due to its interaction with delayed ACKs. Brooker concludes that TCP_NODELAY should be the default setting in today's applications, as single-byte packets are rarely used anymore.
author: Marc Brooker

title: Bleeding Heart: Reflections On Using The Law To Make Social Change
summary: Law changes do not always change culture. The author calls deep social impact "culture-shifting" and says it needs broad scope, legitimacy, and strong enforcement. New Zealand showed legal reform alone can leave cultural attitudes unchanged.
author: Stoddard, Thomas B.

title: Stephen Gaskin, Hippie Who Founded an Enduring Commune, Dies at 79 - The New York Times
summary: Stephen Gaskin, a former Marine turned hippie guru, founded the Farm commune in Tennessee after leading followers from San Francisco. The Farm grew into a long-lasting community known for collective living, businesses, and wide-ranging volunteer work. Gaskin promoted spirituality, self-sufficiency, and practical outreach until his death at 79.
author: Douglas Martin

title: Book Review: The Artist's Way
summary: The Artistâ€™s Way is a flawed but effective self-help book that helps blocked creatives by using simple daily exercises. The key tool, Morning Pages, is three pages of freewriting each morning that clears mental clutter and reveals true feelings. Starting Morning Pages can cause upheaval as ignored problems surface, so begin only when you can handle the disruption.
author: Ozy Brennan

title: Jacob Clarkâ€™s Post
summary: Good architecture reduces the biggest risks to delivery. Focus on the few decisions that threaten scalability, integrity, security, team flow, or time-to-market. Defer other choices until you have evidence and need.
author: Jacob Clark

title: Yves Hanoulle (he/him) ðŸ‡ºðŸ‡¦ ðŸ³ï¸â€ðŸŒˆâ€™s Post
summary:
If I look at the past +10 years, I think the hardest message to bring to teams is: plan less. I start collecting data as soon as I can and I look at:

what was
- planned: by counting, and story points (if they have them)
- added during sprint
- removed during sprint
- delivered
I then calculate the total for all these numbers of the last 10 sprints

What I have learned:

1) Most (all?) teams plan consistent more then they can chew
2) at least 20% unpredictable work gets added
3) Many teams don't remove work when things get added
4) Most stories are longer then 1 sprint (I saw an average of 12 sprints)
5) In many cases the so called "most experiences developer" is the hardest person to convince (not a manager)
6) No one has any idea of the real velocity
7) When people say a team is unpredictable, in most cases they are rather predictable (as in consistent deliver about the same amount of work) yet their promises are all over the place: sometimes over promising and next sprint under promising. Mostly because of 6
8) They don't know the lead time, not per work item, not average
9) The delivery frequency is all over the place 
10) strict delivery rules for planned releases, yet almost no rules for urgent fixes
11) no data on nr failed releases 
12) no data on recovery time: how long does it take to fix a problem in production

Eg they think they are doing scrum, but they don't
I started by saying it was the hardest message, also the one where I have most succes with.

My adviceÂ 
13) start collecting data on all these numbersÂ 
14) yes the extra work might be unpredictable, yet in most teams the % of extra work is rather consistent or cyclic
15) keep a buffer for the extra work that is at least as high as your current % 
16) split work into smaller work that can be delivered and tested in a week or less
All teams tell me it is impossible in their work. In 90% of the cases they are better in it a year later
17) find and show the consistency in these numbers

title: Is Query Optimization a â€œSolvedâ€ Problem?
summary: Query optimization is far from solved because wrong estimates of intermediate result sizes (cardinalities) break plans. Major errors come from unknown parameters, poor join selectivity estimates, and wrong ways of combining predicate selectivities. Learning approaches and better statistics help, but they donâ€™t fully fix correlations, redundant predicates, or star-schema intersections.
author: Guy Lohman

title: From devastation to wonder as Kangaroo Island bushfires lead to cave discoveries
summary:

title: The Fork Awakens: Why GitHubâ€™s Invisible Networks Break Package Security
summary: GitHub serves commits from a shared fork network, so requesting a repo by commit SHA can return code from a fork instead of the named repo. Package managers call GitHub's API but get no warning that the commit lives only in a fork, so they can't protect users. GitHub could add an API option to require that a commit exists in the specified repo, letting tools opt in and prevent this supply-chain risk.

title: Price of a 'bot army' revealed across hundreds of online platforms
summary:
Researchers at Cambridge launched COTSI, a live index tracking prices and stock of fake account verifications across 500+ platforms worldwide.  
The data show cheap SMS verifications in the US, UK and Russia but high costs in Japan and Australia, and spikes on messaging apps before elections.  
The team says SIM regulation and platform transparency could help curb this booming market for bot armies and influence campaigns.
author: University of Cambridge

title: Growth is a Poor Man's God
summary:
We built a civilization that treats growth as a moral duty.  
People worship more â€” followers, revenue, progress â€” because it replaces inner purpose and gives easy direction.  
But endless growth is impossible on a finite planet, and chasing it keeps us from learning how to stop.

title: Excerpt: 'On Writing'
summary:
If you want to be a writer, read a lot and write a lot.  
Reading widely teaches you what to do and what to avoid.  
True writing comes from joy, practice, and time spent inside the work.

title: Story Points Revisited
summary: The article explores the author's current thinking on story points and highlights their misuse. The author argues that using story points to predict project timelines is a weak idea and tracking actuals compared to estimates is at best wasteful. Managers' pressure to deliver more and comparing teams are potential issues that arise with the use of story points. The author suggests slicing stories into smaller ones of high value requiring little time to do as slicing offers better value compared to story estimates.

title: Understanding Agile, Scrum, and Kanban
summary: Agile arose to replace rigid, document-heavy project methods with adaptive, customer-focused ways of working. Scrum uses fixed, time-boxed sprints and defined roles to force regular inspection and adaptation. Kanban optimizes continuous flow by visualizing work and limiting work-in-progress; many teams blend both approaches to scale agility.

title: AI Magnifies Your Clarity...or Confusion
summary: Your company's success with AI may not happen how you think. It will merely amplify the culture that already exists. Less about tech, more about clarity and empathy.

summary: Science shows supportive people make hard tasks feel easier. Longer friendships make challenges seem smaller. Start a tiny daily "Done" group to share progress and avoid facing goals alone.

title: Rob Zuberâ€™s Post
summary:
Teams succeed in different ways; DORA found seven team archetypes.  
AI amplifies existing team dynamicsâ€”it helps strong teams and worsens weak ones.  
The key is building collaboration, clear ownership, and culture so AI actually improves outcomes.

title: US Financial History and Reforms
summary: U.S. financial history shows a repeating cycle: innovation and risk buildup lead to crises that prompt big regulatory reforms. Government backstops for large firms create moral hazard and shift private risk onto the public. Lasting stability needs credible resolution rules, stronger safeguards, and closing regulatory gaps.

summary:
The Federal Reserve must balance independence with public accountability to keep inflation low and the economy stable.

The Fed also oversees payments and bank supervision to protect financial stability and support its monetary goals.

summary:
Test-driven development (TDD) makes developers write tests before code so features are verified early and regressions are reduced.  
TDD adds upfront overhead and a learning curve, so it may not suit small projects or retrofits.  
Combining TDD with approaches like BDD or ATDD can balance thoroughness with practical business requirements.

title: The Surprisingly Complicated World of SMS: Emoji SMS Reactions
summary:
Android implements emoji SMS reactions by sending a specially formatted copy of the original message with hidden metadata characters and the emoji.  
These hidden Unicode characters mark the text as a reaction for Android, while other phones just show the emoji and quoted text.  
Quoting the original and adding the emoji can force UTF-16 encoding and greatly increase message size, causing multipart SMS and higher costs.

title: Minimizing The Impact Of Human Errors Using Relational Risk Analysis
summary: Relational risk analysis (ReRA) models how human errors (system A) can pass through primary systems (system B) to cause harm. Using SRS diagrams and risk registers helps estimate probabilities and document risk-reduction actions.

title: How to Be Pragmatic as an Engineer
summary: Pragmatic engineers choose solutions that work within real-world constraints, not theoretical ideals. They prioritize simple, useful features, avoid premature optimization, and trade off complexity for maintainability. Ask clear questions early, build iteratively with proven tech, and reduce scope without losing value.

title: You can't manage what you can't understand
summary: Effective project management requires understanding the complex systems involved, not just measuring inputs. Managers must adapt their strategies, much like smart cruise control in cars, to respond to changing conditions. Relying solely on traditional methods, like Gantt charts, can overlook crucial factors for project success.

title: How Did REST Come To Mean The Opposite of REST?
summary: The term REST has been widely misused in the computer programming industry, with many people referring to any HTTP-based interface as a REST API. However, the true meaning of REST is centered around the concept of hypertext as a constraint. In order to be considered RESTful, an API must be driven by hypertext, with the API information necessary for interaction contained within the response itself. Unfortunately, most JSON APIs fall short of meeting this requirement, as they lack the self-describing nature of hypertext. Despite this, the term REST has stuck and is often used to describe APIs that are not truly RESTful.

title: Portfolios Across the U.S. Wealth Distribution

This economic change reduces costly incidents, rehiring, and further departures.

title: The forgotten Einstein: how John von Neumann shaped the modern world
summary: John von Neumann was a brilliant mathematician who played a crucial role in shaping modern technology, including computers and artificial intelligence. He was also involved in military projects, helping develop the atomic bomb and game theory, which impacts economics and social sciences today. Despite his significant contributions, von Neumann remains less known than his contemporary, Albert Einstein.

title: Festina lente: A Roman emperorâ€™s guide to getting stuff done
summary: The article explores how the Roman emperor Augustus practiced "festina lente," meaning "make haste slowly," to achieve success through thoughtful diligence and balance. By avoiding procrastination, setting reasonable deadlines, and making time for creativity, individuals can apply this principle to improve decision-making and problem-solving in their personal and professional lives. Augustus' approach of balancing speed with careful planning serves as a timeless strategy for achieving goals effectively.
author: Kevin Dickinson

title: Autodeskâ€™s John Walker explained HP and IBM in 1991
summary: Big companies like HP and IBM focus on short-term margins and cut investment when profits dip. Cutting R&D and marketing to please Wall Street leaves firms vulnerable to smarter, risk-taking competitors. Autodesk warns that obsessing over accounting metrics can kill future growth and innovation.
author: Robert X. Cringely

title: The Hacker's Diet
summary: The Hacker's Diet is a practical guide for losing weight and maintaining it, aimed at busy professionals like engineers and programmers. It offers both computer-based tools and paper alternatives to help users track their weight and diet effectively. The book is available in multiple formats, including EPUB and PDF, making it accessible for various reading devices.
author: John Walker

title: The New Calculus of AI-based Coding
summary:
The authorâ€™s team uses AI agents to write most code, with humans reviewing every line.  
To keep quality at 10x velocity they must speed up testing, deployment, and coordination to catch and revert bugs quickly.  
Agentic development can lower costs for stronger infrastructure, but the whole development lifecycle must be redesigned to succeed.
author: joemag.dev

title: In Praise of Slow Software Engineering
summary: Software should be built at the right tempo, not the fastest possible pace. Slow engineering means patience, clarity, and care so systems and teams stay reliable and humane. Rushing trades long-term safety and understanding for short-term output.
author: Russ Miles

metadata.site_name: A Space to Think: Notes on Software Development

title: Security Brutalism Fundamental Controls
summary: Security Brutalism focuses on simple, practical controls that make systems resilient. Strong identity, data protection, asset visibility, patching, segmentation, zero trust, monitoring, and rehearsed response keep attackers out and operations running. The aim is not perfection but readiness to survive, adapt, and continue after failures.
author: THE SECURITY BRUTALIST

title: How do we tell truths that might hurt?
summary: Sometimes we discover uncomfortable truths that we must tell even though doing so brings personal and professional risk. Computing science often stays silent and avoids hard truths, harming its integrity and progress. Many common tools and languages and sloppy practices cripple thinking and endanger reliable software.
author: virginia.edu

title: Investigation Updates and Community Call to Action
summary: Safe{Wallet} is investigating a sophisticated state-sponsored cyber attack that occurred on February 21, 2025, with help from Mandiant, a cybersecurity firm. The attack compromised a developer's laptop, allowing the attackers to bypass security measures and access sensitive information. The Safe{Wallet} team is working to restore services and enhance security, while urging the community to improve transaction verification processes to prevent future incidents.
author: Safe.eth

title: Turning the Security Flywheel
summary: The text discusses how to enhance security programs using a flywheel approach, focusing on reducing control costs and embedding effective controls into business systems. It emphasizes the importance of using threat intelligence to drive security improvements and create demand for targeted information within the organization. Finally, it highlights the need for continuous monitoring and collaboration across teams to sustain effective controls and foster a culture of security.
author: Phil Venables

title: What is Web5?
summary: Web5 is about giving people autonomous control of authentic data and relationships. Authentic means verifiable provenance and integrity. A set of decentralized technologies (DIDs, VCs, DWNs, ZKPs, etc.) enable this goal.
author: Timothy Ruff

title: How many pillars of observability can you fit on the head of a pin?
summary: The author argues that the â€œthree pillarsâ€ of observability are a marketing myth, not a technical truth. Treating signals (logs, metrics, traces, profiles) as separate pillars creates costly silos and poor UX. Better is unified, structured telemetry so engineers can query the same data without vendor-driven duplication.
author: mipsytipsy

title: Ralph Wiggum as a "software engineer"
summary: Ralph is a simple technique that runs a prompt loop (a Bash loop) to build software. It can replace much outsourcing for new projects by iteratively tuning prompts to fix defects. Using Ralph, the author built a new programming language and achieved high ROI on contracts.
author: Geoffrey Huntley
content_html:
That's the beauty of Ralph - the technique is deterministically bad in an undeterministic world.

Sounds "unpossible" to me.

title: 'Rough Consensus and Running Code' and the Internet-OSI Standards War
summary: The article explores the importance of "Rough Consensus and Running Code" in the development of Internet standards during the 20th century. It highlights the role of informal mechanisms in coordinating technological change and the conflicts between the Internet and OSI standards. The success of the Internet was attributed not only to technical achievements but also to organizational innovations led by pioneers like Vinton Cerf and Robert Kahn.
author: A.L. Russell

title: A Cloudy Crystal Ball -- Visions Of The Future
summary: David Clark warns that the Internet faces big forces: new real-time services, commercial networks, and security threats. Poor security will push networks toward firewalls and application relays, breaking openness. He urges better system security, scalable addressing, and practical standards through rough consensus and running code.
author: David D. Clark

title: Pioneers of the Internet
summary: David Clark and Stephen Wolff helped design the Internetâ€™s open, permissionless architecture. Clark set its technical rules and ethos; Wolff moved it from government labs into wider academic and commercial use. Their work made the Internet flexible, global, and governed by rough consensus rather than central control.
author: Carey Pietsch â€™10

title: How Anarchy Works: On Location with the Masters of the Metaverse, the Internet Engineering Task Force | Imagining the Internet | Elon University
summary: The IETF runs on practical testing and broad agreement, not leaders or voting. Anyone can join and help shape Internet standards by trying ideas and seeing what works. This culture helped the Net grow and may keep it healthy into the future.
author: Elon University

title: Keeping the Internet fast and secure: introducing Merkle Tree Certificates
summary: Merkle Tree Certificates (MTCs) make internet security faster and simpler by reducing the number of signatures and keys needed in TLS handshakes. They group certificates into batches, allowing clients to verify many certificates efficiently using a single proof. This approach helps protect against quantum computer threats while keeping web connections secure and speedy.
author: Luke Valenta

title: Long Hours Impact Developer Productivity
summary: Studies of the "996" work system (9amâ€“9pm, six days a week) show long hours hurt developer productivity. Chronic overtime increases burnout, mistakes, and turnover. Shorter, sustainable schedules improve output and quality.
author: consensus.app

title: Giscus comments integration
content_html:
I added comment functionality to the timeline site using Giscus, a comments system powered by GitHub Discussions.

Why Giscus

Requirements for a comments system were simple: no database, minimal maintenance, and direct moderation within the existing workflow. Giscus fits these constraints by using GitHub Discussions as the backend. Comments appear on timeline items and blog posts, stored as GitHub Discussions and manageable within the repository.

Implementation

The integration has three components: global configuration, per-item control, and rendering.

Global Configuration

Comments can be disabled site-wide via config.ts:

export const config = {
  commentsEnabled: true,
} as const;

When set to false, comments are hidden everywhere. Individual items can still disable comments via hashtags.

Per-Item Control

Specific items can disable comments using the #nocomments or #nc hashtag. This works across content types:

  • Blog posts: add the tag to markdown frontmatter
  • Timeline items: add the hashtag in content text or as a tag

Rendering

For blog posts, Giscus loads with a pathname mapping strategy. Each post gets its own discussion thread. The script loads when the page loads and renders below the content.

For timeline items, Giscus loads dynamically when opening an item. The script is removed when closing the panel to avoid conflicts. This keeps the timeline responsive.

Technical Details

Configuration

Giscus connects to the chasemp/timeline repository with the category "Ideas" (category ID DIC_kwDOQDOMbM4CxLZb). The mapping strategy is "specific" for timeline items, using the item ID as the discussion term. Blog posts use pathname mapping.

A custom theme in giscus-custom.css centers the sign-in button and positions it at the top of the comments section.

Error Handling

If Giscus fails to load, the comments section hides after a 10-second timeout. This prevents displaying empty sections and keeps the interface clean.

References

  • Giscus documentation
  • GitHub Discussions configuration

title: Reflections: The ecosystem is moving
summary: Software must constantly change because the technology and user expectations keep evolving. Federated communication protocols are slow to adapt, making centralized services more practical today. Open source centralized networks offer control and flexibility without the drawbacks of federation.
author: Signal Messenger
